summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Bronson (Widescreen Edition)
Review Date: 2010/12/31
Store: Tom Hardy  (Actor),     Nicolas Winding Refn  (Director)    Rated:    R    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Action & Adventure
Product Description: ['Product Description', "In 1974, a misguided 19-year-old named Michael Peterson (Tom Hardy) decided he wanted to make a name for himself and so, with a homemade sawed-off shotgun and a head full of dreams, he attempted to rob a post office. Swiftly apprehended and originally sentenced to seven years in jail, Peterson has subsequently been behind bars for 34 years, 30 of which have been spent in solitary confinement. Shot from an intelligent, provocative and stylized approach, Bronson follows the metamorphosis of Mickey Peterson, who nicknamed himself Charles Bronson, into Britain's most dangerous prisoner.", 'Amazon.com', "Tom Hardy's performance in the lead role burns right through", 'Bronson', ', the somewhat true tale of a real guy who, once the movie finishes, you\'ll be very glad is still locked up in an English jail. There\'s no obvious reason why Michael Peterson became what he proudly calls "Britain\'s most violent prisoner." His upbringing was normal, his parents meek but loving; he was even married with a child when, in 1974, he attempted a robbery that landed him in the slammer for the first time. Peterson saw this as "an opportunity to sharpen my tools" and make a name for himself; and that he did, eagerly taking on half a dozen guards at once and regularly spending time in solitary confinement (at one point for 69 straight days). A stint in "the loony bin," where he killed another patient, followed, as did incarceration in a hospital for the criminally insane, a brief period on the outside (having been "certified sane," he went to live in an uncle\'s whorehouse, found work as a prizefighter, and fell in love), and then a permanent return to prison, where he decided to change his name to Charlie Bronson (after the American actor) and, improbably, became a pretty decent painter (a climactic scene with his art teacher perversely invokes the Belgian artist René Magritte). Not all of this really happened, but director and cowriter Nicolas Winding Refn\'s film is hardly a documentary; with its saturated color palette, surreal framing devices (Bronson tells some of his tale to a rapt audience in a large theater), and frequent use of black humor, this is a highly stylized and often strange piece of work. Hardy, who has also been seen in Guy Ritchie\'s', 'RocknRolla', "and will be in George Miller's fourth", 'Road Warrior', "epic, delivers an extreme performance; sporting a shaved head and a John L. Sullivan handlebar mustache, he is a credible if occasionally cartoonish presence, a leering, profane, joyously violent cockney madman. Extras include interviews, a making-of documentary, and a featurette detailing the extremely buff Hardy's training for the role.", '--Sam Graham']
Average Rating: 4.4
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Mystery & Suspense', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, AC-3, Closed-captioned, Color, Dolby, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Nicolas Winding Refn, Tom Hardy', 'Language': 'English', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 33 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'R (Restricted)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 0.01 Ounces', 'Item model number': '10275', 'Director': 'Nicolas Winding Refn', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, AC-3, Closed-captioned, Color, Dolby, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 33 minutes', 'Release date': 'February 9, 2010', 'Actors': 'Tom Hardy', 'Subtitles': 'English, Spanish', 'Studio': 'Magnolia Home Ent', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: This is positively the strangest movie I've seen I think in my entire life.  It's basically a prison movie on acid and makes A Clockwork Orange look like an episode of Friends.  It's stylishly filmed and Tom Hardy is fantastic but so so strange.
Review Title: totally bizarre
Rating: 4.0
--------------------------------------------------

Average Rating: 4.5

Review Text: Terrible, terrible movie. One of Stone's worst, and that's saying something. The cherry on top is the very awkward Eli Wallach cameo.

Product Title: The Tomorrow War
Review Date: 2021/07/03
Categories: Suspense, Drama, Compelling, Frightening
Product Description: ['Time travelers arrive from 2051 to deliver an urgent message: 30 years in the future mankind is losing a war against a deadly alien species. The only hope for survival is for soldiers and civilians to be transported to the future and join the fight. Determined to save the world for his daughter, Dan Forester teams up with a brilliant scientist and his estranged father to rewrite the planet’s fate.']
Average Rating: 4.1

Review Text: The Tomorrow War is a confusing mess of a movie. The directing is bad and don't get me started on the ridiculous plot. Not recommended.

Bronson (Widescreen Edition)
Tom Hardy  (Actor),     Nicolas Winding Refn  (Director)    Rated:    R    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Action & Adventure
['Product Description', "In 1974, a misguided 19-year-old named Michael Peterson (Tom Hardy) decided he wanted to make a name for himself and so, with a homemade sawed-off shotgun and a head full of dreams, he attempted to rob a post office. Swiftly apprehended and originally sentenced to seven years in jail, Peterson has subsequently been behind bars for 34 years, 30 of which have been spent in solitary confinement. Shot from an intelligent, provocative and stylized approach, Bronson follows the metamorphosis of Mickey Peterson, who nicknamed himself Charles Bronson, into Britain's most dangerous prisoner.", 'Amazon.com', "Tom Hardy's performance in the lead role burns right through", 'Bronson', ', the somewhat true tale of a real guy who, once the movie finishes, you\'ll be very glad is still locked up in an English jail. There\'s no obvious reason why Michael Peterson became what he proudly calls "Britain\'s most violent prisoner." His upbringing was normal, his parents meek but loving; he was even married with a child when, in 1974, he attempted a robbery that landed him in the slammer for the first time. Peterson saw this as "an opportunity to sharpen my tools" and make a name for himself; and that he did, eagerly taking on half a dozen guards at once and regularly spending time in solitary confinement (at one point for 69 straight days). A stint in "the loony bin," where he killed another patient, followed, as did incarceration in a hospital for the criminally insane, a brief period on the outside (having been "certified sane," he went to live in an uncle\'s whorehouse, found work as a prizefighter, and fell in love), and then a permanent return to prison, where he decided to change his name to Charlie Bronson (after the American actor) and, improbably, became a pretty decent painter (a climactic scene with his art teacher perversely invokes the Belgian artist René Magritte). Not all of this really happened, but director and cowriter Nicolas Winding Refn\'s film is hardly a documentary; with its saturated color palette, surreal framing devices (Bronson tells some of his tale to a rapt audience in a large theater), and frequent use of black humor, this is a highly stylized and often strange piece of work. Hardy, who has also been seen in Guy Ritchie\'s', 'RocknRolla', "and will be in George Miller's fourth", 'Road Warrior', "epic, delivers an extreme performance; sporting a shaved head and a John L. Sullivan handlebar mustache, he is a credible if occasionally cartoonish presence, a leering, profane, joyously violent cockney madman. Extras include interviews, a making-of documentary, and a featurette detailing the extremely buff Hardy's training for the role.", '--Sam Graham']

prompt:
Based on this purchase history, analyze and summarize this person's genuine preferences and patterns in under 256 words. Think step by step:

    1. First, identify consistent patterns in ratings and sentiments
    2. Next, observe common themes across product purposes and use cases
    3. Then, note recurring quality preferences and price sensitivity patterns
    4. Finally, synthesize these observations into core preferences

    Remember to:
    - Focus only on keywords and  trends supported by multiple interactions
    - Avoid repeating specific product names or details
    - Base conclusions strictly on the provided purchase data

    Here's the purchase data:

    === Purchase Information ===

Review Date: 2010/12/31

Shot from an intelligent, provocative and stylized approach, Bronson follows the metamorphosis of Mickey Peterson, who nicknamed himself Charles Bronson, into Britain's most dangerous prisoner.", 'Amazon.com', "Tom Hardy's performance in the lead role burns right through", 'Bronson', ', the somewhat true tale of a real guy who, once the movie finishes, you\'ll be very glad is still locked up in an English jail. There\'s no obvious reason why Michael Peterson became what he proudly calls "Britain\'s most violent prisoner." His upbringing was normal, his parents meek but loving; he was even married with a child when, in 1974, he attempted a robbery that landed him in the slammer for the first time. Peterson saw this as "an opportunity to sharpen my tools" and make a name for himself; and that he did, eagerly taking on half a dozen guards at once and regularly spending time in solitary confinement (at one point for 69 straight days). A stint in "the loony bin," where he killed another patient, followed, as did incarceration in a hospital for the criminally insane, a brief period on the outside (having been "certified sane," he went to live in an uncle\'s whorehouse, found work as a prizefighter, and fell in love), and then a permanent return to prison, where he decided to change his name to Charlie Bronson (after the American actor) and, improbably, became a pretty decent painter (a climactic scene with his art teacher perversely invokes the Belgian artist René Magritte). Not all of this really happened, but director and cowriter Nicolas Winding Refn\'s film is hardly a documentary; with its saturated color palette, surreal framing devices (Bronson tells some of his tale to a rapt audience in a large theater), and frequent use of black humor, this is a highly stylized and often strange piece of work. Hardy, who has also been seen in Guy Ritchie\'s', 'RocknRolla', "and will be in George Miller's fourth", 'Road Warrior', "epic, delivers an extreme performance; sporting a shaved head and a John L. Sullivan handlebar mustache, he is a credible if occasionally cartoonish presence, a leering, profane, joyously violent cockney madman. raw_response:
SUMMARY:
This individual exhibits a strong preference for stylistically unconventional and provocative films, evident in their affinity for ratings around 4.0 to 4.7 for compelling and unique narratives. They demonstrate a clear disdain for poorly executed films, frequently giving low ratings (1.0), particularly when they find them tedious or confusing. Common themes in their reviews highlight a focus on violence, dark humor, and complex character portrayals, indicating a taste for gritty and intense storytelling.

Price sensitivity appears low; the individual prioritizes quality and engaging content over affordability, as shown by the stable high ratings of select films despite varied price points. Additionally, they favor content with significant thematic depth and originality, steering away from typical mainstream productions.

Overall, their core preferences include a penchant for innovative action and drama films, vivid storytelling, and a critical eye towards mediocrity. The recurring dissatisfaction with conventional plots suggests they seek out films that challenge norms and deliver a distinctive viewing experience.

target_interaction.title: Heartfelt
target_interaction.text: A wonderful set of eight stories about life.
